dc:description: MYBPC3 was originally evaluated for autosomal recessive DCM by the ClinGen DCM GCEP on 16 May 2025. MYBPC3 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive DCM in 2019 (Kolokotronis K, et al., PMID: 30924982). Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data. Two probands with DCM have been reported in two publications (Kolokotronis et al, PMID: 30924982; Blagova et al, PMID: 33101033). One probands was homozygous for a small in-frame deletion and the other compound heterozygous for a whole gene MYBPC3 deletion and an MYBPC3 missense variant.  This gene-disease association is supported by multiple animal models (mouse), expression studies, and rescue studies in two mouse models. MYBPC3 has not been assessed in any other autosomal recessive conditions but has been assessed separately for autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (limited, May 16, 2025), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (definitive, October 7, 2021), arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (limited, August 6, 2019), and congenital heart disease (limited, July 8, 2024). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. More evidence is needed to support the relationship of MYBPC3 with autosomal recessive DCM. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on 16th May 2025 (SOP Version 10).
curationReasonDescription: Curation group decision to downgrade classification to limited due to the genetic evidence being driven entirely by VUS's from cohort studies with no strong pedigree based data and limited experimental data. Furthermore the recent large cohort study Mazzarotto et al. (PMID:31983221) demonstrated no enrichment of MYBPC3 variants in cases vs. controls.

evidence.dc:description: reduce as a there is a mixed phenotype of DCM with concurrent LV hypertrophy and only partial rescue of phenotype

Injection of lentiviral vectors encoding full-length MYBPC3 directly into the myocardium of male 8/26 week MYBPC3-/- mice improved but did not completely rescue the in vivo contractile function (decreased LVEDD size and increased FS compared to MYBPC3 -/- mice but were still significantly different to WT mice)
evidence.rdfs:label: MYBPC3-/- Mouse rescue expt

evidence.dc:description: Reduced due to presence of LVH, unsure if DCM specific

Homozygous mice bearing mutated MyBP-C alleles are viable but exhibit neonatal onset of a progressive dilated cardiomyopathy with prominent histopathology of myocyte hypertrophy, myofibrillar disarray, fibrosis, and dystrophic calcification. Echocardiography of homozygous mutant mice showed left ventricular dilation and reduced contractile function at birth; myocardial hypertrophy increased as the animals matured.
evidence.rdfs:label: MyBP-Ct/t mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Reduced score as there is a mixed phenotype of DCM with concurrent LV hypertrophy and only partial rescue of phenotype
Improved LV function
evidence.rdfs:label: Giles_mouse rescue

evidence.dc:description: Score reduced to 0.25

Demonstrated pronounced DCM-like contractile phenotypes (impaired systolic contraction force, faster decay of calcium dynamics and calcium desensitization) in MYBPC3–/– cardiac microtissues contracting against stiffer fibres.
evidence.rdfs:label: MYBPC3-/- iPS cells

evidence.dc:description: reduced as no information provide about LV wall size and unclear how accurately this relates to the human variants

significant decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction (%EF) and fractional shortening (%FS) in TG hearts, compared to NTG hearts at 3 months of age, and a further deterioration at 6 months (p < 0.05), indicating progressive HF. There was increased fibrosis and cross-sectional area of cardiomyocytes from TG, compared to NTG hearts. In vitro studies revealed increased interfilament lattice spacing and rate of tension redevelopment, as well as faster actin-filament sliding velocity within the C-zone of
the transgenic sarcomere.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lynch_mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Show using cosedimentation binding assays, that the 4 N-terminal domains of murine cMyBP-C (i.e. C0-C1-m-C2) bind to F-actin. Electron microscopy and light scattering analyses show that these domains cross-link F-actin filaments, implying multiple sites of interaction with actin. Phosphorylation of the MyBP-C regulatory motif, or m-domain, reduced binding to actin (reduced Bmax) and eliminated actin cross-linking.
evidence.rdfs:label: MYBPC3 and F-Actin Interaction

evidence.dc:description: Used dot blots to show the interaction of c-terminal regions of MYBPC with the Ig-I 11-domain super repeat in the A-band of TTN
evidence.rdfs:label: MYBPC3-TTN Interaction

evidence.dc:description: MYBPC3 mRNA localized in human and mouse embryonic heart tissue.
evidence.rdfs:label: Embryonic human and mouse MYPBPC3 mRNA

evidence.dc:description: Western blots showing the expression of MYBPC-3 in extracts from the left ventricle of rabbit heart
evidence.rdfs:label: Rabbit Heart MyBP-C

member.rdfs:label: 3-II-1
member.detectionMethod:
WES using the Illumina NGS TruSight Cardio Sequencing panel, did not include FLNC
Complete deletion of maternal copy of MYBPC3 - used multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) and Array CGH to confirm a deleted region on chromosome 11 encompassing the MADD, MYBPC3 and SPI1 genes.

evidence.dc:description: Default score for AR missense per DCM GCEP 0.5 per variant. Reduced 0.25 per variant because consanguinity could not be ruled out.
Default score for AR truncating variant 1 point per DCM GCEP; Complete deletion of maternal copy of MYBPC3
Default score for missense AR variant per DCM GCEP 0.5 + 0.5 pts for de novo
